bibl.title: Letter from E.J. Scannell to Henry Rose Carter, December 24, 1924

div1.p: Scannell reports on the yellow fever work in Brazil. He offers his opinion on the methods by which the yellow fever work is conducted.

div1.head: Letter from E.J. Scannell to Henry Rose Carter, December 24, 1924
div1.opener:
RUA DA CAMELLEIRA, N.o 1
1.o ANDAR
TELEPHONE CENTRAL
CAIXA POSTAL, N.o 387
I. H. B
Brazil
DEPARTAMENTO DE SAÚDE PUBLICA
COMMISSÃO DA FEBRE AMARELLA
BAHIA, BRASIL
December 24, 1924.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
On my return from the northern states (Ceará and Maranhâo)
I found your letter dated October 29th. awaiting me.
The immense amount of work you put into the communication
demonstrates clearly that you yet are able to do a great deal
of work. I am glad that is so for I feel that the service needs
you but also it appears to me you should be very careful about
overdoing. I only recently heard that you were at Panama - that may
however have been an error since things frequently become twisted
or changed enroute here. If you were there you must have found many changes
since the days when you walked the ties on the old Panama railroad-
good days they were too, many of them but now going back and finding new
faces everywhere must be rather distressing. I have never been back
although I should enjoy passing through the cut near where I was stationed
by your orders during the last days of 1905.

I am so glad you were kind enough to enlighten me as to some of your
methods in arriving at certain conclusions from old and at the best
confusing histories. As you state, those cases with anemia and with
a long history of illness, many dying months later after arrival
at home must have been malaria.

I am sorry I did not see your ‘Place of Origen of Yellow Fever’ but
Doctor White has not mentioned it so perhaps he did not receive a copy.
We here are all very ignorant of what is going on outside our own
province - I really wish we might be allowed to know more as to what is
taking place. Down here we all feel isolated and are obliged to get what
information we can from the A. M. A. Journal and similar publications.
RUA DA CAMELLEIRA, N.o 1
1.o ANDAR
DEPARTAMENTO DE SAÚDE PUBLICA
COMMISSÃO DA FEBRE AMARELLA
BAHIA, BRASIL
TELEPHONE CENTRAL
CAIXA POSTAL, N.o 387
2.
I have just returned from Ceará where I spent some three weeks
with Doctor Smith.

As you perhaps know we are working the capital of Ceará (Fortaleza)
only but I thought we should know something as to the interior of the
state so with Doctor Smith I visited most of the big towns and cities
there - a most interesting country I found it but wild- mostly desert
and both hot and dry.

I had two very interesting visits with the Governor of Ceará and he
was pleased to recall the fact that he was acquainted with you - it
seems he travelled with you and Doctor Guiteras when you were down
here on the survey.

As to the situation here - we do not know of any cases of Yellow Fever
at the present time any where in the country- the last case I saw in
the interior of Bahia during October. The work goes well and it appears
to be a case of holding on now. All our people have done well and
since Doctor Beeuwkes came all are anxious to get away to Africa.
You mentioned hearing from Carr - yes, he has done quite a bit of
research along old lines- all new to him however and always interesting.
I have been working up a survey which I hope to publish later on, showing
various features of our work, giving hazards (mosquito breeding)
as we have found them in different localities, containers found in the
homes favoring the development of Aedes perhaps is the better term,
and our methods of handling them.

Here in Bahia we have two chief hazards - the water box, usually up under
the roof in kitchen and one or two earthern ware jars (called porrao) which
I am sure you are acquainted with.

The water boxes have been sealed and the jars are covered - the few cisterns

tanks and barrels have been fished. Our index here is running something
under one per cent. To better secure the cooperation of the people
we have been working to eliminate all mosquitoes and I am sure it has been
a good investment. Bahia and Ceará were our two hard places. Ceará
with a population of about 80, 000 has no running water and as you know
that means the storing in the home of whatever water the people can
get hold of- in fact there it meant anywhere from two to five of the
big water jars to a house. The jars here stand about a meter high and
favor Aedes. Doctor Smith had quite a problem on his hands especially
in view of the fact that the disease was not actually present which
is a big factor in getting the cooperation of the people.

However he (Doctor Smith) has his index around 3 and everything appears
satisfactory.

Recife (index about 2.7) is also making a good showing but that is an
easy town to work since there is an abundance of water in about 50 per cent
of the city limits.

After two years without a vacation I feel the need of some cold weather
and on Doctor White's return I am in hopes to get away north - he really
does not need me more since we have plenty of local Directors and they
should be well able to carry on with an occasional word from Doctor White
at Rio. Doctor White has not been well the past year here and I am in
hopes he will be permitted to remain there some time for I am satisfied the
cold air will do him a world of good.

I trust this finds you carrying on. A Happy New Year to Miss Carter,
yourself and Henry - too late for wishing you all a Merry Christmas
but no doubt you all and one anyhow.

DEPARTAMENTO DE SAÚDE PUBLICA
COMMISSÃO DA FEBRE AMARELLA
BAHIA, BRASIL

Catharina is doing well apparently - it is interesting to know that
nearly every state here has some Katarina or other- some indian
maid or other who saved some shipwrecked person and helped establish
this wonderful country. Iracema of Ceará is the most pathetic
case it appears to me. ‘The land of Iracema and the Carnaúba tree’
applies to all Ceará territory.

In spite of an occasional setback, as you state, I too, feel that we will
win through. But Doctor, dont you think we should go slower and not
rush in and out of a country? Just because we do not get reports
of the disease for some months does not necessarily mean that the
disease has been exterminated. For instance here - the city of
Bahia was cleared up something over a year ago - it was as you well know
the big endemic centre yet only this last October on getting rumors of
the disease as being present in the interior I had no difficulty in
finding it within 50 or 60 miles of here - it had been running about
from fazenda to fazenda for some six months or more - in the region of
Santo Antonio de Jesús. It was one of your regional endemicity
affairs. No doubt we still have cases there unrecognized, unreported
or both.

Again thanking you for all your trouble in advising me as to some of your
deductions, I beg to remain,
div1.closer:
Very respectfully yours, E. J. Scannell Doctor H. R. Carter,
Assistant Surgeon General,
United States Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
